title: If 'electricity means flow of electrons' do electrons come out of their shells and atoms? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, the electrons left their atoms, came out the shells when the metal was first formed. If we have a neutral copper atom, then we have a set of electron-orbitals or “shells” surrounding the nucleus. The electrons are trapped, they’re part of the copper atom. But if instead we have many atoms forming a metal, something weird happens. The outer electron “shells” all merge together. The electrons leave their original atoms, and start orbiting all through the entire piece of metal. (Really, this effect defines the “metal” concept.) It’s as if the electricity which had been frozen and trapped inside atoms has “melted” into a liquid. It’s like an “electric fluid” inside the piece of metal. (This “fluid” is also called the ‘electron sea,’ or the ‘ocean of charge.’) Copper behaves something like a water tank, where the “water” can swirl around inside, even while the copper remains unmoving. (The water is the metal’s common electron-cloud; its sea of negative charge.) If we form the copper into a long rod, then the rod behaves as a pre-filled pipe full of fluid. Bend this rod and connect the ends to form a closed ring, and now we have a “complete circuit” where the movable charges can flow along, even while the solid ring remains still. In other words, all electric circuits seem to contain “drive belts” inside them. When the closed belt of electrons starts to slowly turn inside a circuit, we call it by the name “electric current.” The belt moves slowly, but the whole thing starts and stops instantly, like a solid belt. —- But here’s a second issue. Electricity isn’t the flow of electrons. Instead, electricity is the electrons themselves, moving or not. In physics we define the word “electricity” as the quantity of electric charge, where Quantity of Electricity is to be measured in coulombs. It’s part of the SI metric system, the MKS standard units. In that case, matter is made of electricity (atoms are made of charged protons and electrons.) Wires are always full of electricity; they contain hoards of movable electrons. Batteries are actually electricity-pumps, and when we turn off the lights, the electricity remains right where it started: sitting inside the wires. But then all the grade-school textbooks contradict the international science standards and definitions. Instead, these books insist that electricity is the motion, the flow, the amperes. They define “electricity” as the flowing motion of the charges. In other words, they don’t know the difference between “wind” versus “oxygen.” Their mistake has caused a hundred years of confused students, as well as preventing the entire public from being able to grasp anything about electricity. As long as everyone believes that electricity is made of moving electricity, or that electricity disappears whenever electricity stops moving, or that “air” and “wind” are exactly the same thing …nobody has a hope of understanding. To slice through the BS is simple. Just accept the fact that Electricity DOESN’T mean the flow of electrons. Instead, electrons themselves are the electricity, protons are the electricity, and any charged particle is a tiny piece of electricity, even when it’s not flowing. The unit called “ampere” does not measure the quantity of electricity, instead the ampere is just a flow-rate. “Ampere” means “Coulombs of electricity flowing per second.”

Yes they do come out. Electrons in the conduction band of the atom are free to move.These electrons constitute the current. Infact conductivity of a material is dependent on the gap between conduction band and valence band. Which is nothing but the energy required to remove electron from the atom
